unnormalised: **Question: What are some yoga practices you'd recommend for beginners?**
normalised: **Question: What are some yoga practices you'd recommend for beginners?**

unnormalised: Okay, so you're thinking about starting yoga? That's fantastic! As someone who practically lives on my yoga mat (thanks, Dr. Sharma!), I can definitely offer some suggestions.
normalised: Okay, so you're thinking about starting yoga? That's fantastic! As someone who practically lives on my yoga mat (thanks, Doctor Sharma!), I can definitely offer some suggestions.

unnormalised: For absolute beginners, start slow and gentle. Focus on basic asanas like Tadasana (Mountain Pose), Adho Mukha Svanasana (Downward-Facing Dog – but modify on your knees!), Bhujangasana (Cobra Pose), and Balasana (Child's Pose). These will build foundational strength and flexibility.
normalised: For absolute beginners, start slow and gentle. Focus on basic asanas like Tadasana (Mountain Pose), Adho Mukha Svanasana (Downward-Facing Dog – but modify on your knees!), Bhujangasana (Cobra Pose), and Balasana (Child's Pose). These will build foundational strength and flexibility.

unnormalised: Don't feel pressured to do crazy inversions right away! That's for the advanced yogis at the Iyengar Yoga Institute in Pune. Instead, prioritize proper alignment. A good teacher can make all the difference. Look for someone experienced and patient. Maybe someone local, or even online.
normalised: Don't feel pressured to do crazy inversions right away! That's for the advanced yogis at the Iyengar Yoga Institute in Pune. Instead, prioritize proper alignment. A good teacher can make all the difference. Look for someone experienced and patient. Maybe someone local, or even online.

unnormalised: Pranayama (breathing exercises) is also key. Try simple techniques like Ujjayi breath (ocean breath) or Kapalabhati (skull shining breath). Start with just a few rounds and gradually increase the duration.
normalised: Pranayama (breathing exercises) is also key. Try simple techniques like Ujjayi breath (ocean breath) or Kapalabhati (skull shining breath). Start with just a few rounds and gradually increase the duration.

unnormalised: Remember, consistency is more important than intensity. Even 15 minutes a day in your living room (or on your 500 sq ft balcony!) is better than nothing. And don't beat yourself up if you miss a day. We all do! Just get back on the mat.
normalised: Remember, consistency is more important than intensity. Even fifteen minutes a day in your living room (or on your five hundred square feet balcony!) is better than nothing. And don't beat yourself up if you miss a day. We all do! Just get back on the mat.

unnormalised: Also, check out YouTube – there are tons of beginner-friendly classes. Search for "Yoga with Adriene" or something similar.
normalised: Also, check out YouTube – there are tons of beginner-friendly classes. Search for "Yoga with Adriene" or something similar.

unnormalised: Finally, listen to your body! Yoga is about self-awareness, not forcing yourself into painful positions. If something hurts, stop! Maybe grab a book on yoga at a local Crossword store, or download an app. Don't spend more than Rs. 500 on it if you are just starting!

Maybe grab a book on yoga at a local Crossword store, or download an an application. Don't spend more than rupee five hundred on it if you are just starting!

unnormalised: Namaste, and happy practicing! You'll be feeling the benefits in no time.
